HOME.TITLE: Energy Web DApp showcase
HOME.SECTION_1_TEXT:
Energy Web is a project that aims to promote a low-carbon ow-carbon, customer-centric electricity system through the blockchain technology.
Every energy asset can be assigned an unique identifies to allow it to be verified and to participate actively in any energy market.
HOME.SECTION_2_TEXT:
The heart of the Energy Web project is EW-DOS, an opensource, public, digital infrostracture.
The whole system is buit on top of three macro compoenets, each with its purpouse:
HOME.SECTION_2_ITEM_2: Utility - Services and abstraction over the blockchain
HOME.SECTION_2_ITEM_3: Toolkit - Frameworks and tools for building applications
HOME.SECTION_3_TEXT:
The main role of the EWC is to ensure that there is consensus on the data and that all applications and smart contracts behave in a deterministic manner.
It is based on the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM), and as such allows the creation of smart contracts and respects all the Ethereum Request for Comment (ERC).
There is also a test-net, called Volta, used to test projects and applications before running on the main-net.
The consensus algorithm is Proof of Authority (POA), based on the AuRA protocol. At the cost of less decentralization, it ensures very high performance.
The token used on the blockchain is called Energy Web Token (EWT).
HOME.SECTION_4_TEXT:
The utility layer consists of a set of EWC-based services that aim to make the entire infrastructure as accessible and inviting as possible for developers.
All services are paid for in EWT.
Three broad categories of services are identified: End-user experience, Multi-platform interoperability, Application performance.

Some examples are:
HOME.SECTION_4_ITEM_1: EWNS - Similar to DNS, it associates human readable domains to addresses on the blockchain
HOME.SECTION_4_ITEM_2: Oracles - Nodes that can be consulted with the Chainlink protocol to receive data of events external to the blockchain
HOME.SECTION_4_ITEM_3: Identity Directory - Smart contract that contains all the Decentralized IDentifiers (DID)
HOME.SECTION_4_ITEM_4: Messaging - A messaging system that uses DIDs to ensure the validity and authenticity of messages
HOME.SECTION_5_TEXT:
Set of frameworks and services designed to create decentralized applications on EW-DOS.

There are two main examples:
EW-Origin - Used to develop applications that support the tracking, transmission and awarding of energy Attribute Certificates (EAC) according to industry standards.
EW-Flex - Open source software for the management of Distributed Energy Resource (DER) and the operations that involve them. Ensures an easy connection to the network, submitting the offers coming from small producers to an authorized operator that acts as intermetiator between the user and the grid.

ENS.TITLE: Ethereum Name Service (ENS)
ENS.SECTION_1_TEXT:
The Ethereum Name Service is a distributed, open, and extensible naming system based on the Ethereum blockchain. It is available on the Energy Web's chains as well.
Similarly to a DNS, addresses are mapped to human readeable domain names instead of hexadecimal values.
The default publicly available implementation allows mapping for: address, reverse addresses, content hashes, ABIdefinitions, public keys, smart contrats interfaces and so on.
ENS.SECTION_2_TEXT:
For an end user, of course, everything is completely transparent. It is up to the DApp developer to integrate the ENS functionality.
There are several libraries that already support this feature, although some manual patching may be required.
In any case, the procedure for solving a domain with ENS is not very complicated:
ENS.SECTION_2_ITEM_1: Normalise and hash the name. (Learn more)
ENS.SECTION_2_ITEM_2: Call resolver() on the ENS registry, passing in the output of step 1. This returns the address of the resolver responsible for the name.
ENS.SECTION_2_ITEM_3: Using the resolver interface, call addr() on the resolver address returned in step 2, passing in the hashed name calculated in step 1.  Alternatively if you are not looking up an address, call the relevant interface function to read the value of interest, e.g. text()
ENS.SECTION_2_TEXT_PT_2: To know more about how ENS works under the hood, visit the official wiki
ENS.SECTION_3_TEXT:
Use the name resolver below to see how convenient ENS can be.
Try searching something with the hexadecimal address first and then use its domain name.
Eg. 0xef131ed1460626e97F34243DAc544B42eb52a472 | tend.ewc

DID.TITLE: Decentralized IDentifiers (DIDs)
DID.SECTION_1_TEXT:
DIDs are uniue identifiers that enable verifiable, decentralized digital identity. They are used to implement Self Sovrain Identity (SSI).
The identified subject can be anything: a person, an organization or a phisical asset to name a few.
A DID behaves like an URL, and points to a DID document, which stored on public permanent storage, like a blockchain.
Anyone can create a new DID at any time, but the claims will continue to refer to a specific DID.
DID.SECTION_1_IMG: A simple example of a Decentralized IDentifier (DID) with its components
DID.SECTION_2_TITLE: A more in deapht look at DIDs
DID.SECTION_2_TEXT:
A DID is, at its core, a URI composed of three parts: the scheme did:, a method identifier, and a unique, method-specific identifier specified by the DID method.
DIDs are resolvable to DID documents, which are simple JSON-LD files. The DID document contains all the informations or claims related to the subject the DID identifies and provides a set of mechanisms which enable a DID controller to prove its control over the DID. They also typically express verification methods, such as cryptographic public keys, and services relevant to interactions with the DID subject.

The controller of a DID is the entity that has the capability to make changes to a DID document. This capability is typically asserted by the control of a set of cryptographic keys.
Note that a DID might have more than one controller, and the DID subject can be the DID controller, or one of them.

Systems that support recording DIDs and returning data necessary to produce DID documents are called a verifiable data registry.
A DID resolver is the component responsible of returning the correct DID document given its DID. This process is called DID resolution.
DID.SECTION_2_IMG: Overview of DID architecture and the relationship of the basic components
DID.SECTION_3_TEXT:
The identity subject needs an identity to be able to prove you possess certain traits or characteristics to a verifier.
The verifier has a number of trusted issuers from which it is willing to accept claims from.
The subject can ask one of these issuers to add a signed claim on its DID document, 
Also, both issuer and verifier must be able to verify that the subject is actually the identity owner. This is achieved through DIDAuth.
This process can take many forms, as specified in the DID document, but a common way is through a challenge sent by the issuer or the verifier to the subject, whose public key they know thanks to the DID document, which in turn will respond by signing with the its private key, proving its identity.

Let's try a real world analogy.
You want to buy alcohol at a bar. To do so, you must be able to prove to the barman that you are at least 18 years old. The barman in this case is the verifier.
You can prove your claim by showing your identity card. 
It is issued from the government, which acts as a trusted issuer for the barman, who will check that you are actually the person pictured in the photo and will be convinced that you are old enough.
DID.SECTION_3_IMG: Possible flow showing how an authentication interaction could use DIDs for autonomous authentication
DID.SECTION_4_TEXT:
Energy web uses DIDs to identify users, organizations and assets. This way, informations about the entity are publicly verifiable.
For example, you could issue a renewable energy certificate and assign it to a specific asset.
Also, to each wallet address can corrispond a DID. This is useful to enstablish a role based IAM system.

IAM.TITLE: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
IAM.SECTION_1_TEXT:
IAM is a set of policies that ensures that only the entities with the right credentials and authorizations can access the resources.
The system first needs to verify the digital identity of the subject and to check the roles associated with it.
The operation is authorized only if the subject has the necessary roles.
To mantain accountability logging may be used to record every operations performed by the subject.
IAM.SECTION_2_TEXT:
To implement a truly decentralized IAM system, some properties must be guaranteed.

The IAM must be censorship resistant.

It means that there is no actor in the system that has the power to selectively limit the information others have access to. This aspect is important because information such as whether a permission or a key has been revoked or invalidated, or whether a permission has, instead, been granted must be publicly available. A blockchain fulfills these requirements by design. Additionally, the cryptographic proofs contained in the transactions allow the offline verification of the data. This is why all the permissions are anchored on-chain and the description of roles are held in an ENS smart-contract.

Information about users and roles must be confidential.

In the Energy Web solution, no third party has the full list of users of an application. This is guaranteed by the permission-granting process, for is the user who stores the claim and anchors it on chain, allowing them to prove they have been granted a certain privilege. Also, because it is a private claim, the contents are provable but not disclosed. The only information an observer can garner is that the user has added a claim to their DID document but not the content, origin, or nature of the claim.

Finally, it must leverage a decentralized infrastructure.

This is achieved by using a combination of the Energy Web blockchain and IPFS, which are both peer networks. An additional layer will make the IAM management even easier: a messaging service that will be provided by the service nodes of the EW-DOS. Each message will be signed by the sender, to avoid any malicious alteration.
IAM.SECTION_3_TEXT:
To show what the IAM can be used for, here is a little demo.

The structure is as follows:
there is the main "unict" organization, which in tern has a "test" sub-organizationi.

Two roles belong to it: "testrole" and "student". You can enroll with your DID to both roles.
Applications to the former need approval from a specific DID, while for the latter anyone with a "testrole" role can approve the request.
Roles can have optional fields containing an arbitrary amount of data of different types.

There is also an app called "TESTAPP" associated with the organization, and it contains has a role, namely the "juniordev" role.

This kind of hierarchy ensures a fine control and flexibility over permissions whithn an organization.
